replies.author: @Sid_Hatfield
replies.text:
At present, Luigi Mangione is the 'accused' killer.  He has only been charged with the murder of the UHC CEO.
It's interesting how even the most well-meaning people are guilty of convicting the accused before he has had his day in court, or before all of the facts, about the murder, are known to the public.   In large publicly promoted cases, the accused is often tried in the media, and in the public eye, before there is any carriage of justice.
For all we know, Brian Thompson could have been targeted by anyone - a rival CEO, a rival member of the board, some guy whose girlfriend Brian Thompson was bangin,' I mean who knows?? 🤷‍♂

replies.text: I know the majority on here will disagree,cuz they're all see the world through the hegelian,pink glasses..But seeking for the means to overcome the pain and boredom ,it's one of the main traits of human nature...There will always be some sort of a opium ,comfort,that the masses,or the individual will seek,whether that would be in form of religion, philosophy, ideologies,getting wasted, seeking irrational amount of pleasures.. Ruling class are just looking for a way how to easily control the masses and as long they play along a irrationality of human nature,they dont need to worry about them loosing their positions.On the other hand,they are just humans themselves,they are also are being caught up in a endless cycle of seeking pleasures and running after imaginary goals,in order to avoid reality of pain and boredom..They just happen to be more sociopathic part of human society, therefore stronger ,more vicious than others, therefore prone to rule ..

author: @-ASTROMAGIC
text: This was deeply illuminating. During the pandemic I had the chance to try a few psychs and did feel them help me make several breakthroughs. Although I wouldn't suggest these to another person without them doing their due diligence with researching. And the angle of psych culture being a part of the CIA's social engineering makes a lot of sense. It just makes me want to live a healthier balanced life even more :)

author: @WylieCullick
text: Interesting conversation  -- thank you for the contribution.  My 2-cents on the acid is it's a heterogenous sample, historically, programmatically:  There are many different manifestations, variations, batches, of LSD.  There are many other confounding factors, confusing the issue further.  I will say I've had immensely transformative positive experiences with LSD-25 in the previous millenium, that may have been some luck.  I don't think they harmed my brain -- could be wrong.  I suspect the very small amount of MDMA I've done did do some harm in that sense -- but even more I suspect covert chemical warfare of a subtle program -- but really just don't know.  My overall sense is that the mkultra controller people discovered a rather coarse instrumentalization of this chemical, without appreciating the (to them, adverse) genuinely positive aspects of these substances -- coexisting with coarse brutal instrumentalizations.  Feasibly, they have engineered successive batches of acid to denude them of all positive aspects.  Last time I did acid it felt like nothing in particular, some vagrant chemical disorienting me.  That's not an objective measurement, perhaps it was golden lsd-25 and my mind so fried by stress my pineal gland can't vibe any more, etc.  Lot's of speculation in the absence of good laboratories, taboo on natural healing really is the heart of the ignorance.

author: @brokenpremise
text: Interesting interview, and while I agree that many progressive movements have been manipulated and made impotent ( over centuries), but reducing all activist movements and people as being CIA ops at their core is a slippery slope, much as the right finds comfort in this. The left can be equally naive. Burning man , which I’ve attended many times as an artist/ hippie freak does not have people spraying LSD on people . That’s just silly. It’s not utopia, but it’s not a sinister plot, though now as Silicon Valley has embraced it, I fear for its future

replies.text: Psychedelics aren't inherently bad no, but it is hugely dependent on set and setting, as well as intentions set before use, as well as to be used very sparingly. But it's undeniable how "psychedelic culture" completely destroyed the effectiveness and direction of the American left.

author: @carrotwax-42
text:
I think there's some good information here but it doesn't seem rigorous.  I hate the term conspiracy theory but this doesn't seem scholarly in terms of being cautious before believing the worst.  Lots of exaggeration here.  As I said, there's some good info here but it's important to have nuance.  


Never been to black rock city but I've been to regional burning man events.  There's a lot of emphasis on safety and it's definitely safer  than a standard festival. 

I agree there's lots to be concerned about.  It's just not black and white and this presentation makes much of the subject monocolor.

replies.author: @gauravtejpal8901
replies.text: ​What is this 'context', pray? If we are to lump together opiates, barbituates, psychotropic substances, hallucinogens, all manner of entheogens and everything else under the sun into a catch-all category of 'drugs', I think it is fair to add sugar to that list.
